title: Embryonic Stem Cells and Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells for Skeletal Regeneration
abstract: Tissue engineering for skeletal tissues including bone and cartilage have been focused on the use of adult stem cells. Although there are several pioneering researches on skeletal tissue regeneration from embryonic stem cells (ESCs), ethical issues and the possibility of immune rejection clouded further attention to the application of ESCs for nonlethal orthopedic conditions. However, the recent discovery of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) led to reconsider the use of these pluripotential cells for skeletal regeneration. The purpose of this review was to summarize the current knowledge of osteogenic and chondrogenic induction from ESCs and iPSCs and to provide a perspective on the application of iPSCs for skeletal regeneration.

motivations: Ethical issues and the possibility of immune rejection have limited the application of embryonic stem cells (ESCs) for skeletal tissue regeneration.
There is a need for alternative stem cell sources for skeletal regeneration, particularly for non-lethal orthopedic conditions.
objectives: Summarize the current knowledge of osteogenic and chondrogenic induction from ESCs and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs).
Provide a perspective on the application of iPSCs for skeletal regeneration.
methods: Review existing research on the use of ESCs and iPSCs for skeletal tissue regeneration.
results: Enhance the understanding of the potential of iPSCs for skeletal regeneration.
Provide insights into the future application of iPSCs for treating orthopedic conditions.
